title:
BlessemFlood21: Advancing Flood Analysis with a High-Resolution
  Georeferenced Dataset for Humanitarian Aid Support
authors:
Vladyslav Polushko, Alexander Jenal, Jens Bongartz, Immanuel Weber,
  Damjan Hatic, Ronald R\"osch, Thomas M\"arz, Markus Rauhut, Andreas Weinmann
abstract:
Floods are an increasingly common global threat, causing emergencies and
severe damage to infrastructure. During crises, organisations such as the World
Food Programme use remotely sensed imagery, typically obtained through drones,
for rapid situational analysis to plan life-saving actions. Computer Vision
tools are needed to support task force experts on-site in the evaluation of the
imagery to improve their efficiency and to allocate resources strategically. We
introduce the BlessemFlood21 dataset to stimulate research on efficient flood
detection tools. The imagery was acquired during the 2021 Erftstadt-Blessem
flooding event and consists of high-resolution and georeferenced RGB-NIR
images. In the resulting RGB dataset, the images are supplemented with detailed
water masks, obtained via a semi-supervised human-in-the-loop technique, where
in particular the NIR information is leveraged to classify pixels as either
water or non-water. We evaluate our dataset by training and testing established
Deep Learning models for semantic segmentation. With BlessemFlood21 we provide
labeled high-resolution RGB data and a baseline for further development of
algorithmic solutions tailored to flood detection in RGB imagery.
